title: Solved Mysteries; or, Revelations of a City Detective
author: Macgovan, James.
snippet: Not far from the little strips of garden attached to the cottages there was a marshy field, and it was clear to me that the footsteps of the thieves crossed that field. The field was a quick cut towards the Bonnington Road, therefore a quieter way of getting off with the plunder. None but a thief would have put a foot in that field unless he wished to leave his boots and stockings behind him.

title: Skagboys
author: Welsh, Irvine
snippet: As ah gits oaf the bus back at Leith, the last gadgie ah expect tae see in a tracky, poundin the windswept boulevards ay the fair port, is Second Prize. — Hey, Rab, man, ah goes as the cat comes hoppin intae view oan Bonnington Road.

title: Memorials of his time,
author: Cockburn, Henry Cockburn
snippet: He was too innocent for it. The last time I saw this simple and worthy man was very shortly before his death, the near approach of which he was quite aware of, at a house he had taken on the Bonnington Road. He was trying to discharge a twopenny cannon for the amusement of his children ; but his alarm and awkwardness only terrified them the more 5 till at last he got behind a washing-tub, and then, fastening the match to the end -of a long stick, set the piece of ordnance off gloriously.

title: Skagboys
author: Welsh, Irvine
snippet: Renton reflecting that no matter how early you rise or how late you turn in, you never see that point where light begins or the first bruise of darkness bleeds in under its fragile skin; the beauty, and the scary, unfathomable wisdom of transition. They head out from the lock-up in Matty's van, stopping at the Canasta Cafe in Bonnington Road, ostensibly for some food, but really to dispense the Valium that Renton liberated from his mother's medicine cabinet. They wash the pills down with milky coffees.
